Of course he had to add oil propaganda. Global warming is well understood by the experts, there are zero questions, take your car to a receptionist instead of a mechanic if you don't know what an expert is. The oceans are rapidly acidifying, the forests are burning, the entire climate is in a state of collapse, the earth is literally dying. Only extreme stupidity or extreme uneducation could ever believe the rainforest was planted, it literally took millions of years of evolution to be created. Even the tiniest knowledge of the complexity of that ecosystem would know that as plain as day. A crazy level of ignorance and stupidity ruined a great podcast.

1 hr in what really strikes me is just how easy it was to convert an illegal goldminer destroying the environment into a purveyor of ecotourism. It really drives home just how most of the smaller outfits (rather than the big multinationals or narcotraffico cartels) are just victims of global capitalism- desperate men born on the "wrong" side of the equator, trying to make a living in the only manner they see available to them. I wonder how many, if given an opportunity, would  prefer to be building eco-friendly lodges, teaching students and tourists about biodiversity, teaching Spanish or Ticuna or Quechua, helping scientists find, count and measure fauna, or  managing foreign labor on "volunteerism vacations".... it would be amazing to take the whole dirty industry and replace it with a positive one, something that still paid but that was safer and healthier for everyone involved, a win/win for everyone.     Obviously dealing with the multinational corporations and narcotriffico cartels wpuld be much harder and a whole nother ball game (though its interesting how once in the Amazon there is little difference between the two: they both employ private paramilitary mercenaries.)

At 0:22, he mentions the penguin that is going in the wrong direction. There are research stations inland in Antarctica that cause the wildlife, such as walruses, to lose their bearings. This is due to the lights and noise produced by these stations. It is the saddest sight to see these animals crying out to their group, so lost and doomed to die.

Cosmicomics by Italo Calvino explores this concept of different worlds, people, separated insurmountably by the void of time. Sending out signs and messages that get read and responded to out of sync, so the connection is always out of reach. Itâ€™s a beautiful depiction of the longing and the ache of being disconnected from this larger family. People that might know you, but canâ€™t, because youâ€™re too far away. Too far in space and time, but also in understanding.   He has a similar story in that compilation where two beings are falling eternally through space, and their paths never intersect. And somehow they hold on to this hope that someday their paths might cross, that maybe the science could bend to their desire to connect.   A lot of us are trying to live with love, connection, compassion at the core of our values that we carry with us. And sometimes thatâ€™s enough - to fulfill whatever purpose we have in this life, or to transcend whatever limitations weâ€™re meant to transcend, or whatever else enough might mean. But there is always a longing, to be connected in a way this world isnâ€™t ready for yet. Maybe that we still arenâ€™t ready for, even though weâ€™d like to be.   ğŸ™ğŸª·ğŸ’«ğŸŒ

I'm 67 yrs old. Born and raised in rural N.E. Alabama,USA. I've witnessed private land clear-cutting timberland (all species) of scopes from 500-2500 acres bordering my property at one time. Seen the once forest floors poisoned to kill natural seeds from regrowing so one species of tree (hybrid paper making pines) can be planted and farmed for a (20-30yr tree crop). I've not seen the forest's wildlife population return back with all the plants, insects, reptiles, amphibians, avians, mammals, all of the varieties it once had. The only good that I received was escaping critters ( mostly insects, birds, frogs, lizards, snakes, and turtles), types that I'd never seen existing here. However, many of them over populated my property. And after a couple yrs they must've died out ( didn't see them anymore). And the common critters seem to be smaller in size now (deer certainly are), turkey almost disappeared. It affects everything. In their world it has to be like an apocalypse. Ppl wouldn't believe the frog/lizard/ and snake cannibalism I observed in the following  yr. Therefore, I hope by being left alone, my natural forested property can be somewhat of a small sanctuary to those critters that remain in my lifetime. I don't foresee tree farming ever diminishing. Please preserve natural forestland, worldwide. ğŸ•Šï¸âœŒï¸ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

I study environmental science, and in terms of the ongoing climate change debate that you brought up, it definitely has merit. But as far as I have learned, the exact outcome is not what we should focus on, because the climate models do contain a lot of uncertainty. What we should be focusing on is the overwhelming amount of evidence pointing towards a changing climate - and taking countervailing action. Because we know what we are doing wrong, and from that knowledge we can act to halt it. Even if it is somewhat unclear what the exact, specific end result of our actions may be.

If youve never been around snake, the idea you have about the strength is way way off. The first i touched a snake i found near a swamp near the temple i was practicing at, didnt remember why i touched it maybe trying to get it to move away from the front gate.  I suddenly felt the disgust feeling similar to what insect gives you and so pulled or picked up this leave so that i didnt have to touch the snake directly, it was a python. I remember the leave was vivid green, as i tried to pick up this snake with a pinching motion, with middle and index finger and the thumb to support, the snake realized i touched it and it started to move away. Its really dumb what i did, coz i dont know there the head was, coz it was kinda coverd altho nothi g happened. I was shocked after touchjng it for maybe .5 seconds. The sheer strenght it has while its just calmly moving away. I imagined it to be softer, but its super hard when it contracts its muscle to move away. Used to think about how people dont just punch their way out of getting eaten alive, i understood right then. Its probably like you girlfriend holding up her guard and trying to fight you. Once you have gripped whatever part of her, maybe you do nt have her under control judt yet, buf that arm or leg is yours. She can punch and hammer fist you all she want but you arent taking damage. Thats the level of leverage it has. Mere miliseconds my hands were in contect with it and trying to pinch and pull, it just moved and i lost the grip immedialy no push pull, it was just gone.

He is not credible. He is talking about 25-30 foot stankes like that's normal, and 30 foot females being fierce apex predators that rule a lake.. and jumping on one so big his arms wouldn't reach around it.  The World Record snake was 38 feet long, and died for the same reasons almost no snakes get near that size, or even 20 foot in length....  Snakes move by alternating betwee increasing friction with the ground and pushing off of the rest of the ribs which are doing so. Basically they are creating points to push off of, and the portion that pushes in this moment becomes the portion that is pessing down to create a friction point to push from in the next moment... over and over ... rapidly. So the snake "slined" from there to here.  The system works great with low mass animals, but as you start approaching a typical snake proportion in terms of 15 feet, it starts to ... break down. The bigger the snake gets beyond typical proportions at around 20 feet... the less effective it is at movement.  A 15 foot snake is burning more than 5 times the energy to move, of one just 10 feet long... and the reduction in efficiency increses disproportionately more than the mass of the snake.  A 35 foot snake can barely function, and typically is only alive because someone is feeding it manually. The One thing he gets right... they shit on you when you try to grab them.   ... Also, just because they go to a location where they will wait (in ambush) for prey, does not mean they aren't actually Ambush Predators. That's actually how ambush predators work.

The man's ability to read the jaguar tracks and explain what was going on is the same as a New Yorker reading a bus schedule.  We learn to thrive in our given environments, and for some reason ... enjoy sharing that adaptation with those unfamiliar.  Animals, are not emotional/compassionate.  Some... dogs for example, have a very limited range of social "emotion" stemming from their "pack" animal origins having such a strong reliance on social groups.  But the way a cow will be "compassionate" in protection of a calf is about instinct to protect the herd, not emotions.  And yes, I worked with animals daily.  We had a large family farm.

I want to start out by saying that this was overall an incredible interview, and Paul seems to be as genuine as they possibly come and has experienced things the average person can only dream of. I have the utmost respect. One thing that disappointed me is his continuing the narrative that one needs a shaman to experience Ayuaska "properly." Let me tell you guys something....NN-DMT or the main active ingredient found in ayahuasca and it is meant for every single person on this planet to experience. It is a molecule that dates back further than we can even fathom. If you don't get a chance in your lifetime to know even a short smoked or vaped NN-DMT experience, you have probably missed out but that's ok, there is always next life â¤. Now, I will admit, it's not for every individuals  peronality type...People obviously have different encounters and experiences, but even the people whom have these "bad trips" know that when they come back, they are altered. Ayahuasca does in fact a lot of times include other alkaloids and can "hit" a bit different, but let's just describe ayahuasca as an extended orally induced NN-DMT trip which is activated and moves past your bbb(blood brain barrier) because of the MAOI that is introduced into the drink or tea. I do enjoy Ayahuasca because it seems to ease you into the "space" or "realm" a bit more and gives you the opportunity to explore this unknown, "impossible" space. It is quite the experience and I recommend you try it if you are at all interested in the molecule. You DO NOT need a shaman to have a "proper" NN-DMT experience, but just someone you fully trust to watch over you and also give yourself a grounding point. I use music for this, for me, familiar music i thoroughly enjoy works best. I advise you do a 15-20 min venture using traditional NN-DMT crystals by means of smoking or vaping(I find vaping for me gives me a more "pure experience"). One thing I will mark as important is make sure your NN-DMT is from a reliable source and if you can find the clear white crystal form...Even better. Yellow is ok, but for me, a bit more foggy I think is the wording I'd use? Also like to mention smoking vs vaping is slightly a different feeling. I believe when you use a flame, you are not getting just the NN-DMT, but other alkaloids as well. So, if you're interested, crawl before you walk and walk before you run...Try a typical trip before you dive into the space for hours. You may not want to or need to be here for hours. 15 mins may be all you personally need. Use a trusted family member or friend that you trust with your life. Eventually, if said friend is also interested, you guys can explore this very real realm together....I'll save that for another time. I'm also not going to go into the God molecule here(5MEO), but same idea. Family or friend you trust with your life may be better than a shaman in these spiritual experiences. I'm sorry to ramble but if you have a real opportunity to have the NN-DMt experience and you have proper conditions, don't hesitate because you think a shaman is the only being that can help you discover this previously unknown world. One last thing, while 5MEO is absolutely a different experience, I recommend "easing in" with a short NN-DMT experience first, then maybe explore that realm a while using ayahuasca if you have access. From there, if you feel like there is more out there you need to discover like myself. If you want to know all the secrets you can possibly know in that small organ we call a brain, but also come to the realization we are literally ants, 5MEO can give you some off the answers and realizations to those bewildering questions you undoubtedly have. Sorry to ramble but i felt the need. One Love â¤ï¸

I loved every moment of this interview bc like Paul finding his sacred place among nature and animals, as a Native Hawaiian I have had a lifelong profound love of nature and all animals and the ocean, and I'd prefer to live among the wild animals and sea creatures than with humans.  My heart burst with joy  when Paul spoke at 2:30 about "that book" by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. which opens with the first line: " â€œEveryone now knows how to find the meaning of life within himself.â€  and I was imagining "that book" throughout his entire interview.   Paul refers to the "Harmoniums" stuck to the walls in a cave on the moon Titan of Saturn. The Harmoniums are like Sea Cucumber slugs, and awaken as pulsating iridescent glowing lights, when one of the space travelers plays music. I imagined Ennio Morricone's The Mission. Originally written in 1959 the space traveler is a millionaire that builds a rocket ship. Eerily familiar?  Just like when the lightning bugs were thick and dense in meadows in Midwestern summers  in the 70s, but how those supernatural magical insects completely disappeared in the 80s 90s from heavy use of pesticides and insecticides, herbicides(glyphosates/Round Up) made by Monsanto now owned by Bayer.  The Harmoniums Paul talks about...are dormant living organisms that come alive to the sound of music played in a cave on an alien planet.  While lying on the dock one hot summer on a lake in Columbia Missouri, I found this forgotten worn .55 cent lavender paperback c.1973 THE SIRENS OF TITAN by Kurt Vonnegut Jr.  Couldn't put it down, and when I got to the part of the cave dwelling Harmoniums I nodded off...woke up hot and dove into the water opened my eyes under water... and lo and behold...in the center of the this little lake in the Ozarks...there were millions of golfball sized white fresh water jellyfish.  It was as if in my dreams I'd manifested Harmoniums.  I wanna go on the Amazon trip with Lex & Paul..!!! ğŸŒºğŸ¦‹

OHMYGAWD quit calling them "black halos!" The sky inside of the halo is the same color as the sky outside of the halo. And neither are black.  Cirrus clouds (those thin, wispy clouds filled with ice crystals that are located very high up- around 20,000 feet) have to be present before we can even see a halo. When you look at the patch of sky that is between the halo and those wispy clouds  that are in front of the sun, the sky only looks like its darker because of the contrast with the bright white. Its just an optical illusion.

Iâ€™m sorry brother, but to think that because you had an experience in the jungle that you then can only do ayahuasca in the jungle, is a shortcut to thinking. Also, because your experience took you on your own personal journey, that doesnâ€™t mean that same experience will be produced by another. In addition, if you get some really good mushrooms and eat a heroâ€™s dose (5.5g) you will definitely experience more than you can fathom. I myself, on lsd have seen the whole universe be born then grow and expand past what we presently know and all the universes secrets have on many occasion then opened up to me. On mushrooms I have seen and communicated with source (god for the lack of a better word), I have gained a perspective and understanding into quantum physics in a way to where my experiences gave me knowledge that I previously had never learned nor had ever known. Iâ€™ve seen a great many things and have even shared visions with others without muttering one word to one another. I have lost all physical form and have lived an entire life that spanned a great many years in a mere moment while on dmt. Many times on many different substances I have been transformed in a way that made â€œrealâ€ life seem like the illusion. There is more to life than what we perceive, and these gifts, these â€œhallucinogens,â€(a word I canâ€™t stand, fore it is way more than seeing something that isnâ€™t there), they can help you see beyond any measure of what you think you know and you will grow from it. No matter if the experience is perceivably negative or overwhelmingly positive, it will always be what you need in that moment. Understand that and you will find out things about yourself that will help you in life. itâ€™s more like seeing what is always there for the first time, and understanding we are part of something so much larger and more profound than anyone can even imagine. My point, try not to project your experiences onto others. Please donâ€™t make people feel like without sharing the same conditions that you endured that their experiences arenâ€™t as important or arenâ€™t on the same level as to what you went through. Each persons journey is individual to that person. Lex has the right idea, run headlong mind, body, and spirit into the unknown and shed your limitations, come out on the other side where limitation is a long dead idea, and find the beauty of life that awaits you. Responsibly and safely  I believe in a long, prolonged derangement of the senses to obtain the unknown. Although we live in the subconscious our pale reason hides the infinite from us. - Jim Morrison

Paul masterfully conveys the beauty of storytelling, nature, and experience, making the first 2/3 of the interview outstanding. However, the last 1/3 introduces confusion as he acknowledges 70% biodiversity loss in the last 50yrs but agrees with Jordan Peterson that weâ€™re all alarmists. Isnâ€™t that pretty alarming?? He describes in detail the horrors of logging, mining and poaching but questions if we should slow industrial progress literally in the face of everything he just claimed devotion to. He also describes the complexity of emotion, intelligence and consciousness of elephants going insofar to say they need their own legal representation, but then scoffs at the idea of veganism and protecting animals where we can. So what, if a tribe in the Amazon munches on monkey skulls, why would that be an argument for the rest of the world? Lastly, Paul says he only cares about protecting the rainforest but simultaneously praises industrial animal agriculture yet literally 80% of rainforest loss is due to beef production. So, while Paul's mind is impressive, a notable disconnection from human ethical responsibility in the modern era surfaces. He could stand to have a conversation with Damien Mander who founded the International Anti-Poaching Foundation and is a vegan.

There is a reason that Jordan Peterson doesn't focus on other minds, it is that his research framework and counselling framework is more an extension of, more or less, Jungian psychology and focuses on sort of mythological archetypes and personality, plus his own personal theological biases add to the mix. He isn't a cognitive scientist, he doesn't come from the cognitive perspective, which views intelligence and even consciousness as a, literally, computational process and as non unique to human beings or even living things. That hasn't stopped Jordan Peterson from described himself as a "neuroscientist" and as an "evolutionary biologist" at various times, seemingly he is aware that his actual paradigm doesn't make him qualified to talk generally about these subjects and he really badly wants to be seen as a general scientific thinker. He is a personality psychologist and former counselling psychologist who wrote some self-help books. He existed for decades without any outside interest, it was only once he started making videos against the inclusion of gender identity under Canadian hate crime laws that his popularity soared, this tied in with the rise of the new right and its backlash against the SJW movement (see Gamergate). He is an inherently reactionary figure (he is nicely employed at the Daily Wire after all). I don't understand how people put him in a similar camp as the like of Sam Harris and even scientists from more hard science perspectives. He is Dr. Phil for young men on the new right, and is just not a very interesting or unique thinker, he is also very thin skinned and has a martyr complex, making him an inherently unpleasant person.

They cut the forest,  then burn the forest, then they  run water through, the sand  particles have bits of gold  in it. Just connect the dots.Then  it rains down into the rivers,  so the mercury recycles back down into the water which is causing birth defects.Through  research we learn the anaconda   instinctively find clay lakes, salt deposits, and they'll wait  for they're prey.. I have a friend that was in the French foreign legion and he told me they went to the amazon for a training exercise.   He said it blew his mind what went on there. One time one of his comrades went to go for a pee in the bushes, and after a min he heard a scream and gun shots, a rapid fire.  He said that his comrade turned around and an anaconda was set up right behind him tensed up, he screamed in fright and fell back shooting hitting the anaconda killing it. They ate it and moved on.  He said days later they came across a white guy who came running up to them as high as anyone he ever saw. The guy spoke Dutch and one of the soldiers was Dutch too. He solider said the guy had almost forgotten how to even use or understand Dutch. They tried ro persuade him to go with them but he refused and wanted to stay where he was..he was living there for years, miles in the jungle where you have no people around you, not even the indigenous lived in this section of the amazon.

The more I learn about Mr. Fridman and his outlook on life, the more I admire and respect this fellow human. He has such reverence and genuine appreciation when he interacts with others.  I haven't seen all the episodes of this podcast, but perhaps someone can tell me about a particular interview or clip that answers this question:  Is Lex living through a great loss or the death of loved ones? His heavy sighs and taking time to formulate his responses before speaking, as well as his reoccurring curiosity regarding mortality, death, love, and the meaning of life, make me wonder to what degree, if any, he is experiencing grief and the loss of those he loves.  I could be totally wrong, but he's so appreciative and grateful for every guest's time and perspective. He seems very humble and full of gratitude, and my intuition tells me that he has possibly experienced a deep trauma or great loss.  I wouldn't "enjoy" hearing that he has deeply suffered. I hope that I'm wrong, but if he has shared any insight into his personal life regarding these matters, I believe it would help me understand him more as a person and very likely become an inspiration in hopes that I can help others and myself who are living through something similar.  If he has not publicly discussed this topic, I fully understand and respect his privacy.  Much love to anyone reading this. May your day be filled with growth, gratitude, and love. I hope your future is filled with the kindest of moments and the fondest of memories. ğŸ–¤

Thank you Alex for having on this guest.  HE'S just amazing with his stories and his lack of fear shall we say in the face of the unknown in the jungle is refreshing. . I recently read the book called THE SIXTH EXTINCTION which I recommend to you.  IT'S not as deep or as fun as this conversation but it talks about the five extinctions that have occurred on the Earth which seemed to match up with five extinctions that I also read about that  primitive people have recorded orally ,  tho unfortunately I don't remember where I read that . I do  rexall  thinking when I began the book The  6th Extinction-- oh yeah,  indigenous  folk said the same thing.       The 6th extinction is the first one that shall be instigated by the homosapien. Believe it or not, after I finished that book, I had a sense of Peace because I felt --well this has happened before. Five  Huge extinctions in the world before Homo sapiens came into the picture and of course the Earth continues to survive. AFTER we destroy all the habitats that are essentialfir  90% or more of the current creatures on this Earth,the earth will go on         I'm also waiting two books I recommend to you THE SOUL OF AN OCTOPUS by SY Montgomery and THE SOUND OF A WILD SNAIL EATING by Elisabeth Bailey.  THOSE are fascinating forays into creatures different from us. After hearing your guest speak about the intelligence  of nature, and reading about the adaptability and intuitiveness of octopuses,as well as the maliability of snails, I frankly do not think human beings are that smart and they definitely are not the smartest creatures on the Earth.   They are uniqueky gifted at destroying the very planet upon which they live though.           One thing I remember so long ago whike traveling  hearing from a woman who was Jewish who  said to me that people have misunderstood what Darwin said. HE did not speak in terms of a species or  individual superseding all others and dominating but what he spoke about was NICHES and that each animal and each group of animals needs to find its niche and that is how life functions. ALL you need to do is to Google Darwin and survival of the fittest and you will find out that phrase did NOT come out of his mouth but actually it wasn't an economist who  grabbed ahold of it & began to use it and later it was attributed to Darwin and he sort of picked it up & used it but nevercwith theme narrow meaning  we've attributed to it.  IT wasn't his intent to justify ruthless calitalism as seen during the gilded age in America and is now once again seeing in these United States   IF you have niches,  then you won't speak of a superior being dominating and destroying those weaker than itself. It seems to me especially hearing your guest speak that actually the way that we live on the earth is  created by the interlocking forms of life in the Amazon  and we don't realize that. BUT without them,  we could NOT exist.       We are a unique species and that we are intent on destroying that on which we live and I don't just mean climate change but obviously the deforestation of the amazing Amazon and many other places. I recall reading that Greece which  I love so much used to be covered with trees and  African deserts  were covered with trees as well.  ALL these deserts are not natural but  accrued over time. I truly think that if we put our minds to it we could deal with the increasing carbon dioxide in the air since that is what plants need and apparently at different stages in the Earth's history there was huge amounts of carbon dioxide on the earth and the plants at that time needed it to survive.  WHAT I have done in my backyard is to plant seven trees while none of my neighbors have any trees in this new development. We were all given one tree in the front yard -although some people's trees have died- but for the most part most people have one tree total. . My trees of course are growing very slowly and they're very small so I'm going to try to research and see what I can do to create faster growing trees because I know that before I die they probably will not have grown that tall. THAT said there's a woman in Africa who got a peace prize who is planted so many trees and there's other people as well  but we actually need every single human being to plant a tree somewhere and every couple that has a child should plant a tree for that child.  BY increasing greatly the number of trees on the earth we will have helped with the increase  in carbon dioxide.        Needless to say the  humility of your guest when  he decides NOT to answer your question regarding climate-change i admire. I too would have to say I to know next to nothing but sometimes common Sense does kick in and therefore causes one to give an idea that may or may not work but in all events it is fun because I love my trees. I live in Central Texas and everything else I plant dies because the heat is too great in the summer but my trees seem to kick back and they make it which gives me a lot of joy. Good luck on your trip with your new friend into the jungle because I sense that you need that now more than ever and you must feel greatly honored that he is willing to take you because you're not necessarily A boy scout at heart and don't have a lot of training in these areas but you couldn't find a better person to guide you. Bonne chance & bon voyageğŸ˜Š

15:05 Person that always inspired me to show the depths man can go to pull thru and live is Leonid Rogozov. He was a Russian surgeon that was part of an expedition to the Antarctic. After completing their expedition; Building a new base at "Schimarcher Oasis". Him and his crew had to hunker down and stay thru the coming winter months. During said Winter months that further cut them off from the rest of the world, more than being in Antarctica already does, Rogozov became very ill. Being the only surgeon and doctor for the expedition he soon diagnosed himself with acute appendicitis. Of course, being the only surgeon. There was no one else to help him. So after enduring extreme pain and knowing that his appendix was about to burst, which would kill him. He made the decision that the only choice was to perform an auto-appendectomy on HIMSELF. Something that had never been done in human history before. Something, he himself wasn't sure was even humanly possible. After all, to reach the appendix; He'd have to open his own abdomen and remove his intestines. . . . Rogozov picked 2 men to work as his surgical assistants and got the station director to act as backup incase one of the assistants fainted from the gruesome scene. None having any medical experience. He gave himself local anesthetic to his abdominal wall. . . After a grueling surgery in which he himself almost passed out from blood loss and pain several times. He fount the appendix with a dark stain at its base. Meaning just 1 day longer of waiting. And his appendix would of all but certainly burst. Killing him. . . Always fount this an incredible story of how far man can push himself when it is required. I recommend anyone reading into this story if interested. Tho, beware! If you have a weak stomach it is very gruesome and many articles of this story also have photos that where took during the surgery. But a very inspiring story of perseverance of someone dealt a bad hand.

This CD has three separate relaxation/meditation sessions on it https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxzpa8CIfZcihW4Z0F_ja0QF3W9KIatrsq guided by a very pleasant and direct male voice. Unlike so many other products of its type, this CD does not have bad synthesizer music, does not feature a phony or affected style of narration, and does not make any bogus claims to be  subliminal  or to  re-train the brain  or any of that balderdash. What you get is 1. a guided meditation for getting into a pleasantly relaxed state of body awareness while taking a stroll (superb for those easing back into a fitness routine slowly after an illness or injury) 2. A nice long breath-awareness relaxation session that if followed diligently can put you into very deep states of full-body relaxation and mental calmness, and 3. a buddhist-inspired meditation session designed to help you develop and maintain feelings of loving kindness toward not just yourself and your friends, but toward people you don't even like. The CD makes no claims to be designed for advanced meditators or for buddhists or hindus/yoga practitioners looking for very deep and esoteric stuff. It is geared more toward the average person who just wants to develop the habit of relaxation and stress relief through natural, healthy means. him, if you happen to be reading this, keep up the good work fella, and I love your accent. I would also like to note that I have never fallen asleep while listening to this product. I would like to kindly suggest to the reviewer who said this CD makes him fall asleep, that he might want to get checked to see if he has a sleep disorder, or if he is simply not setting aside ample time for restful sleep at night. A healthy person getting adequate rest at night should be able to go into deep states of mental relaxation without dozing off, if not all the time, then most of the time.

My great grandmother who was Quapaw taught me how to talk to animals. It is actually really easy and the more we listen the more they speak. Well some just aren't interested in us but the ones that are will talk if we listen. When I was a kid my cousin from my dad's side was teasing and saying my grandma could talk to animals and the wind and whatnot so I just asked her. The way she first explained it changed how I viewed animals from that point on. She just kinda grunted, got her dog's attention, nodded her head towards the door and the dog got excited and ran to the door to go outside. I knew she had just asked it if it wanted to go outside and it responded with a clear and obvious yes. Dogs are kind of a special case and I'd guess just about every person that has spent any real amount of time with them knows they can communicate with us. She wasn't limited to speaking with dogs, neither am I and neither are you. Humans tend to forget that we are animals too and that self distance means many of them don't trust us and if for no other reason than the simple fact that most of us are obviously lying to ourselves. Why should something else trust us if we're obviously lying to ourselves?  There are isolated tribes that have a language which lacks the concept of the color blue. When they're shown a line up of various shades of green and blue they can almost always tell various shades of green apart easier than people who speak a language from a more modern society but are simply unable, or have an extremely difficult time, distinguishing between some shade of green and what we would clearly see as blue. In some sense there is no blue and just one single band of light but through our language we have habituated ourselves to separate the already extremely narrow bandwidth of light we can perceive even further. Some languages have a concept of blue and some don't. This same sort of thing happens with "speaking with nature". It isn't that there is verbal communication, although certainly non-verbal in the case of animals, but still a communication of a sort. While I don't necessarily actually literally believe in animism, using a similar conceptual framework allows for one to have an entire palette of colors most don't have. Some objections I hear to this usually come from people who like to pretend, I'm being literal in my use of "pretend" here, to be uber logical and scientific minded. The vast majority of those people base a good chunk of their beliefs, worldview, etc on consensus but, depending on how one does that, it can be a textbook example of appeal to authority. For example, the statement "The majority of X specialists believe Y therefore Z" if Z is almost anything other than simply restating Y then it is an appeal to the authority of X. In addition to that, many of these people never question things like the axioms underlying the logic they love so much. If I can find a counterexample to an axiom should I actually say it is axiomatic or dogmatic?

1:43:34 Lex you are talking about evolutionary adaptations that do not seem to actually aid function, but are still favored in the selection process. Not sure where I read it, maybe Carl Sagan's Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors, or Jared Diamond's The Third Chimpanzee, but what I remember is that, for instance in some species of birds, the long plumage says, "I'm so strong and healthy, I can have these long, essentially useless and cumbersome feathers and still thrive!" So the longer and more cumbersome, while not ultimately preventing survival, the more those individuals are "preferred." The human parallel is, for instance, young men who drink heavily, but don't die!   Or engage in other risky behaviors. As long as they don't die, they are showing off to those around them how "tough" they are. (And yes, there are still, potentially harmful, long-term repercussions, of drinking for instance, but those generally do not have an impact Before procreation succeeds.)

I work at the Visitor Center at Green River Lake in KY where we keep a female black rat snake along with other native reptiles and fish. I grew up in another part of the state catching snakes, with my "mentor" being "Jim" from Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom. I appreciate that snakes represent an important part of our own brains, which may be part of the reason we project so many negative human intentions onto them. Hearing Paul talk about handling the snakes in the wild and being able to share that experience with visitors almost brought me to tears. It made me realize that snakes can actually be "Ambassadors" of the wild, maybe moreso than so many other animals. It made for a real paradigm shift in my thinking. 3:00:31 it's good to switch off your TV and use your time more wisely but that only has a negligible impact on your energy consumption. You need to check what consumes most energy before you make such statements to so many â€“ heating is the top energy consumer.  Also you lump together people being "so terrified" or being such with reasonable well-thought-through needed responses to climate change,. These changes include stopping to eat beef and reducing meat consumption. It's not a anti-human sentiment, that would be not doing anything about it.  Animal agriculture alone would lead to failed global climate goals of dietary patterns persist as is (but they're getting even worse as Chinese etc get richer). For example half of grains and land used for such are used to feed animals. More info can be found at WP:"Environmental impacts of animal agriculture".  In terms, of pointing the responsibility to consumers as in "you're evil" â€“ that's indeed the wrong approach, policies are needed that facilitate and reward sustainable behavior instead of the opposite. An interview with a person doing policy studies or so would be nice.

To all other listeners:  And of course animals have compassion and are capable of thought.   Just because their brains are different and (most often) smaller doesn't mean they are not intelligent and able to communicate/understand communications or to have deep thoughts.   There are other ways of thinking - Nature does it differently.

Cycle of life "When you sweat, you can hold out your arm and watch the condensation come off your skin. It rises up and join the clouds and rain back down in the afternoon. Then, you drink from the river and it starts all over again." - Paul Rosolie  Beauty of truth "We live in such a human world where everything is debatable, religion, politics, and perspectives on everything. And then you get down to this point where if we do not figure out something out, the river is going to rise and take the boat. That is the truth and ain't nobody gonna argue with that. There is a beauty because then all of us are united in that truth." - Paul Rosolie  "Authencity is the greatest currency." - Paul Rosolie  Lulu "There was an orphan anteater (Lulu) on the river. JJ got me the baby and we were, like, we are gonna rewild here. I have spent weeks and weeks with her on my back. Crawling through jungle, teaching her to find ants, giving her milk, falling asleep with her on my chest. She was able to also communicate emotions. She needed it. So if this animal did not have the physical touch, if I did not hold her all day long, she would throw tantrums, she would go shred something, she would ruin the woods. She would start having traumatic response not having intimacy... It is different, it is very different. And you realize just like person's public persona when they are out on the street in Manhattan. It is gonna be very different than when you are on the couch with them on a Tuesday night" - Paul Rosolie  Stop killing the things that keep us alive Paul Rosolie: "I feel like I have the dumbest job in the world. Like, guys, please stop killing the things that keep us alive. The Amazon regulates the global climate, produces medicine, it is home to indigenous people, it is beautiful. Rainforests only cover 3% of land mass, it is not much to ask." Lex Fridman: "If you leave their home untouched, they will figure out how to have sex and multiple. Excepts for pandas, apperantly, you have to convince."  Close to death "One of the same black caiman that had come for the fish, he came right next to me, this giant 16-foot crocodile. He just looked at me. And it was funny because I was not scared of him, I was scared of them (uncontacted tribes). The things you learn in these moments, the appreciation for your parents, what a hug feels like. It brings new this new joy for life." - Paul Rosolie  Beauty of life "I think I am on mushrooms all the time genetically somehow because when I go out in nature, it is just beauty. The other thing that fills me with awe is our own mind, like the biology of these things firing. Basically, the biology of any living organism because it is like an ecosystem. These cells came together, they somehow function, they delegate, they mostly operate in a local way. First of all, it is just like you said with the anacondas, you start out as a tiny snake and you became giant. When you are a tiny snake your are prey for anything, when you are giant snake, you are prey to no one. And just that whole process, same starting with a single embryo, single cell as a human. And through the embryogenic process, constructing this giant human that is able to have limbs, move around the world, think about things, write books and so on. So you see that that is incredibly beautiful and all that is here on Earth. So actually I was being a sorr of poetic about aliens. I think I can spend 99.99% in terms of filling my mind with awe and beauty just looking down here on Earth." - Lex Fridman  "Do something good on Earth. Go help somebody that needs it. Go help your neighbor, whatever it is." - Paul Rosolie  Testing ground Paul Rosolie: "I hope that this is a testing ground. Whether it is aliens or Gods, this is something crucially important. Lex Fridman: "I would like to believe beauty and good is possible."

I hunted most of my young life for food. Elk, deer, mountain lion, and bear. Just to be clear, stalked the animal. Never used salt licks or corn piles, cameras or anything that have us an advantage. Had to be very sneaky and quiet using the wind and cover. And never downed a lion or bear myself. For about 10 years, I was a hunting guide for the 1% mostly. People like one of the greatest quarterbacks from the NFL from Denver with his kicker and 2 of the largest linemen you can think of. Congress men, owners of water companies, very high ranking military people and a few people that were stunningly rich, not Elon Musk rich but pretty close. I can remember the moment my thoughts of killing animals changed forever. 3 baby crows were dancing around in my yard almost looked like they were playing but the parent crows were flying around making all kinds of nose for over an hour. Now the reason I even went out was I was finished with the noise. I figured it out immediately that they had fallen out of the nest. So I spent the next 2 hours trying to catch then and put them back on a branch in the tree. I was so proud I went to my neighbor's and was about to tell him about it. As I was walking up his drivewa, about 75 yards from the the street to his house. I could see him with his pellet gun shooting the baby crows. They fell back into my yard and sure enough died. I was crushed by this and something inside me just changed that day. I never spoke with him again except for the screaming at him that day"what have you done"!!!! I had to pick these baby crows up that before took me hours. Now a single dark moment in time it took. I've never killed another animal from that day forward.

He interrupted a green anaconda couple doing some star light love making! And I agree there is not an aggressive snake species on the planet there are only defensive snakes. I hear stories all the time of people claiming snakes racing towards them to get them, which most of the time is a mistake in direction. The snake typically just chooses a direction and books it, most snakes have very poor eye sight and not realizing it's the same direction as a person will sometimes mistakenly move their direction. I've heard it put like this before: A snake versus a human the snake loses almost every time. Even if it's a venomous snake and it bites you it's still going to die, because it's going to take time for the venom to work. They have no desire to fight with a human The bite is only a last defense a final ditch effort to escape what it views as a lethal threat. I was born without the fear of snakes spiders and all what people consider creepy crawlies. I love them all and would be in heaven in the Amazon looking for anacondas. It's a life long dream to visit the Amazon.

I understand, only because I have an adventurous son. I taught him to read and count early and that's where it ended- his real education was time with my dad, a biologist or building and fixing things with his dad. My son could identify unique classifications of birds, animals plants and trees by age five.   By second grade his teachers tried to get me to put him on medication because he was bored, energetic and he didn't like sitting at a desk and staring at a one dimensional piece of paper for eight hours. He was a normal boy but we let him get tested, then I refused to put him on pills, especially when I learned that every child in his class got a recommendation to get tested and every child got a prescription. It's a situation of government subsidies, the doctors and the schools get a financial kickback.   l think that we're evolving, cells have memory, we carry the history of our ancestors inside of us and we need to tap into that, at our core level, if we're going to know the truth about human history and cycles of destruction. Other than learning to read and to do some math, school is a monumental waste, they're teaching an agreed upon set of  lies and with the level of indoctrination now it's become downright detrimental. Kids are being conditioned for conformity, legal slavery unawares and institutionalized living and thinking.   A boy's natural thirst for adventure- that adrenaline rush- is channeled into sex, drugs, fast cars and otherwise embracing the dark side. Or they resign themselves to their fate and escape into technology and/or conforming. I don't think enough people realize that we are going to be living off the land in our lifetime, and it will be incredibly rewarding and humbling..some will choose to lose their soul in exchange for inconvenient convenience, it's essentially bondage leading them blindly into the mouth of the dragon. We would do well to start workshops teaching children- and even adults- basic and advanced survival skills and natural living. The world is so incredibly vast, parts of it have yet to be seen by human eyes, so beautiful -yet people pile on top of each other on a concrete slab, a prison without bars. That isn't truly living.

Presently we believe that information cannot travel faster than the speed of light, which means that communication between distant points in space will experience latency that would be a major challenge to a spacefareing race.  If, however, there is a means of communication that is instantaneous across any distance, then obviously space travelers would make use of that technology.  We may possibly be constantly being bombarded by alien messaging - it just might happen to be based on physics and technology that mankind has not yet discovered.  With that said, I do believe we may find that we co-exist with other advanced species here on Earth.  They just decided to move to "a better neighborhood".  If there is another, far more advanced, life form on Earth, then it could be extremely dangerous to our own species.  As soon as such a life form were to conclude that we posed an existential threat to them, they could almost certainly unleash a biological attack that would wipe out the human race on Earth.  Were that the case, we would do well to behave ourselves.

This was such a breath of fresh air. Thoroughly enjoyed the epic, eye opining jungle adventures shared by  Mr. Rosolie. His job seems to be sheer labor of love. We need more people like him. Like the guest mentioned, some of us have definitely become ecological orphans not really acknowledging the symbiosis between  Earth and us . Mother Earth has not abandoned us but we have forgotten her, taking for granted her unconditional love. If anthropomorphizing helps us understand things, how can we so narcissistically ignore other living beings whose habitats we share. I remember playing with tiny frogs during monsoon (there were tadpoles in our fountain), finding red, orange and yellow lady bugs in spring in my backyard, spotting a beautifully colored newt slithering away somewhere, earth worms, leaches, grey mango bugs, Monarch butterflies, dragon flies and yes we had fire flies too. I don't see them anymore. Most frogs cant survive the heat in summers now, also, thanks to the pesticide sprays used for Dengue mosquitoes ( which I'm sure are man/lab made ) kill other harmless bugs. Similarly heavy commercialization of cities ( including my city ) has caused so many animal and bird species to migrate and disappear within a span of just 15 to 20 years. If this is not alarming then what is? Where will this end? I also  believe that life on this planet is a test of our humanness. Hope we pass it. This podcast dropped like an existential crisis.  Thankyou for enabling  this conversation.

Certainly, climate systems are complex. So is human psychology; this shouldn't dissuade the study of either. Scientific study of complex systems/complex adaptive systems has been hampered by reductionist approaches but is by no means "too complex" to begin to understand. We often aim to comprehend systems and their behavior by reducing them to their individual parts with increasingly powerful techniques while often ignoring synthesisâ€¦ forgetting the overarching, long-term trends in evolution: biological diversity emerged relatively slowly, made leaps in complexity and diversified; changed the entire biogeochemistry of the earth system (cyanobacteria) resulting in "long term" trajectory: a homeorhetic system characterized by states of relative stability and resistance to perturbation... until certain thresholds are passed... then there are phase changes...  ...liquid skin/new skin/super glue works great for most neotropical microbial pests - staph, strept, leishmaniasis (if caught early).  if only there were a longer lasting and effective treatment to rid neotropical ecosystems of their true threat... invasive spps...  alas... i have no cure nor quarter... patience

The division between man and nature, man and animal, man and truth, reality..  all these are pseudoscience.    There is no factual evidence of it.     In fact the reason we can make those divisions are proof that they can be overcome..   just by letting them be, and let entropy have its way on them .   But the divisions have a function.   To relate to the world, and engineer that which is around us, our bodies, our neurology, our psyche..   social, societal engineering..     but take all these elements away, and we still are capable of living..    to mistake the tool for the fact, is the cause of many problems,..  that division has to be forced, and connection has to be forced.      No matter our actions we are part of nature.   Even if we throw atom bombs.    So the question is not, are we part of nature..   it is how can we re evaluate our traditions of engineering to create a society which creates less suffering in the world..   even though peterson is right in saying the future is uncertain, this should be no excuse for apathy.  For ignoring the violence of imposing a tradition.   Societies should be ready to evolve with the moral spiritual and technological evolution that individuals bring about..     but we should be at all times conscious that the human mind is by its nature biased.      Not just peterson, but every scientist is biased in a way, having trust in their own research..  they are just being human.   So i dont take them that seriously..  i am human as well..    whatever happens happens..  it does not disturb me.      Concerning moving to another planet.   It seems pretty cool.   I would love to travel these places.  And find out the many ways we could have been wrong about them misinterpreting data..   i would love to find out as well about what exists beyond the measurable local region of spacetime..   imagine finding out about ways to travel not based on relativity theory but quantum mechanics..   maybe we underestimate ourselves in that respect.        Escaping earth, i feel is nonsense..  this billionaire fantasy..   completely destroying all life on earth, would create a space similar to whatever we would colonize..  but in some way it makes sense, like creating a seed bank..  just the time and energy to terraform other planets..  anything we see as a danger right now, it would probably either have happened, or we would have overcome..  This amazon guy is pretty cool, worth a look into his approach..    I have been following up on ai a little..  athene (esp george carlin) and vedal (neurosama) are doing some great stuff on twitch..  using allready visual auditory information..  george carlin doing live programming and showing the dangers of ai,  neurosama playing minecraft (badly) , reacting to videos, interacting with chat and doing co ops with other streamers..  I can see why some see consciousness there..  i would not be surprised..   pan psychism and animism sound very intuitively true to me.   Even rocks feel alive to me..   i am fortunate not to have to scientifically prove it..   but it feels real to me as an individual..   i can celebrate that beauty with no concern for others

Lex, the largest anaconda, a Green Anaconda, recorded over the course of hundreds of years, like 5 to be in the ball park, is 30 feet long and 12 inches in diameter. It is possible for there to be a 40 foot anaconda but not one that is around 30 or 36 inches in diameter. It would have to be something like 90 feet long to get to that circumference. Reticulated  Pythons get that large but not that long. An animals morphology is determined by biology. Yes there are anomalies and mutations. So far in hundreds of years of meeting up with Anacondas there are no validated reports of anything even approaching the size the Jungle Protector described.. There were tales of such just as there are tales of Civil War Soldiers meeting up with a pterodactyl. Possible but very much not likely. It is good your guest wants to protect the Jungle and does something more than complain and donate. Being misleading will not produce good results over time no matter how good the motivation. You know this about the Government. Know it about people.  Also Anacondas are very much alone creatures, Well unless it's mating time and then there are mating balls but no lounging snakes laying about on each other. Just a bunch of over eager males trying to get the female. Once that's done the snakes part company. There was a LOT of this kind of stuff in his answers. He would do far better if he were to either spend some actual time there or, more likely, just not embroider things as 100% for certain there are far too many who know this sort of =stuff or can look it up. But the embroidery does cause one to think maybe it's ignorance. Did you know a rather large proportion of Charities and Causes are money making scams for the Principals? That is also 100% for certain. I would not like his to be a scam. Be Well!

Paul's body of work - sacred and invaluable.  Paul's joy at feeling a fish wriggling and writhing from tha agony of that hook in its mouth - not so much sacred.  I was negatively startled to see Paul use that same "spiritual, primal moment" woo woo justification that is common among hunters....you know....like Rogan does and gets gleeful about.  Im in south FL and helped rescue a pelican 2 weeks ago that had 3 ( three) triple hook clusters down its throat.  The sanctuary was able to get them out.  Ecxruciatingly painful.s  Too, that hunting preserve concept is morally torqued.  The only reason it accomplishes the sizable good that it does is because there is the unavoidable capitalist, profit driven platform supporting the operation....you know....the animals have been commodified to a price that the marketplace is comfortable with.  I promise you, $30k customers get concierge guidance as to where to go and find a hapless creature to slam and explode a blob of lead into....for fun.  Some organized game traps calling themselves game "preserves" even "corner" an animal so the customer can shoot from the comfort of safety- like a Jeep.  In short, no profit, no need to do this to animals.  NEVERTHELESS, Paul has done for the creatures under his care quantities of good that I can barely imagine or dream about.  God bless his work.

Very soon the day has run out and now its already too late because 50% is already too much a price to pay. Its better to fight. Mongols were merciless in that they did not even want the people to surrender. They ended up with more if people chose to fight. They wanted to deny people the chance to surrender. Ayahuasca is certainly very beautiful in the Amazon, talk about set and setting, but it is wrong to imply it is more 'real' in the Amazon, or even that it is very different to mushrooms (increase your mushroom dose it can take you to similar places). Yes, people can do it in "Brooklyn" and it is such a profound substance that it can, in its full glory, reach a terminal patient who is unable to travel into the Amazon jungle to do it, actually it will very easily take them out of their own bodies, let alone Brooklyn, given an adequate dose. I have lived in S.A. and have been interested in this for quite a long time, and I feel that many "gringos" are coming in hopes of a spiritual experience and getting a tourists trip with 'shamans' who have no traditional history with the medicine, concocting brews with questionable materials and ratios. This is not to say the real thing doesn't exist, but the potential for a bunk experience exists in the Amazon too. It has without any doubt become a tourist industry, and has been for decades now, this guys 'station' is no different even if they do great things there, it is evidently a tourism business too.  Fortunately, the medicine transcends the people or environment surrounding it, but only if it is actually the medicine, meaning it is prepared and dosed properly. Most people who have done both forms of DMT; edible and vaporised, typically will report that the Western method of vaporizing is far more powerful, while the Ayahusca or Pharma-huasca is more easy going, when a breakthrough is achieved the duration of effect on the body is irrelevant, vaporised it typically lasts about 15 minutes physiologically, but it can experientially feel like lifetimes, a breakthrough is harder to achieve on Ayahuasca and most people will never receive that dose in a tourist setting. Both do much of their work through integration after the experience, it does not matter much which you take. Many including myself believe the experience you get is the one you need, every time, regardless of where you are or who you do it with. Ideally it is best to do it with experienced and educated people, whether that is a true lineage shaman taught by their elders or just people who have made it for a long time and sat a lot of trips, it can even be yourself after seeking the knowledge and preparing the medicine with wisdom shared freely, in detail, thanks to many compassionate humans for many decades now, if there are no better options. Respect is the most important element, treat it with reverence because it is a powerful tool and all powerful tools have the potential to cause great harm if used poorly.  DMT is found in hundreds of species of plants all over the world, and there are cultures other than the Amazon tribes who likely used it, Egyptians worshiping Acacia trees, one of the richest sources of DMT, is likely no coincidence, we are discovering more and more about the psychedelic use in the Elysian mysteries and many other traditions around the globe. The Amazon is amazing, and a trip there without any drugs would be a mind expanding experience in itself, but don't try to own something that belongs to all living on Earth, it is one of many portals.  There is no reason to gate keep the medicine by implying it is more "real" in the amazon, and the only people I ever see doing that are people who don't know and echo or those with a vested interest in selling the experience. Anyone I know who has broken through would go out of there way to help prepare and guide someone who was put on their path in need and asking for help, if they knew how to, and do it for free, without a second thought. Having had that experience they know exactly what it means when they are put in that position. Which leads me to question Paul's experience with the substance, I think he is a beautiful person who clearly idolizes noble people who stand up for the weak and tries to live in alignment with those principles himself while balancing the often egoic requirements of this world to make a living and find a mate, I like him a lot and would love to find myself with nothing but a matchstick in the amazon with him, I can only imagine all I could learn and see, but I don't think this is a subject he has enough knowledge on to make such a strong statement, I believe it is important people know they can get this medicine anywhere in the world and it does not discriminate.  This has fascinated me most of my life, happy to share any information freely if you need help. As with love, it belongs to you already.

The reason people raise the alarm and call for such extreme measures re: climate change is not because they think we should immediately stop burning fossil fuels or something as drastic as that. They call for such extreme measures because they know that stopping global industry and halting the forward march of capitalism is at best a herculean task and at worst impossible. Anyone raising concern about what climate change scientists advocate for are fundamentally on the wrong side of the argument. Take universal healthcare in America, polling the American public and something like 2/3, a large majority, of people agree that it's a good thing. But good luck stopping the entire for-profit medical industry and the politicians they pay for. Even when the public agrees on something, actually changing the systems in place, like fossil fuel usage, takes such monumental effort even with a consensus. So of course climate scienctists will be raising the alarms if they think we're headed into something dangerous, if they spoke mildly about it, almost assuredly nothing would happen. People shouldn't feel bad about watching TV like in the example Paul gave, but they should feel bad that our tax dollars fund the largest polluter in the world, except for China, which is the US military. On top of that, fossil fuels are a FINITE RESOURCE anyway, the systems WILL have to change, and everyone, except oil CEO's and politicians, will agree that being proactive is better than being reactive.

Lex, about that penguin you talked about, the one you thought was going to meet his lover, and that the penguins made really strong bonds with each others. Well, perhaps you haven seen that documentary about Antarctica, and this kind of penguins - but in one documentary we can follow the penguin couples, and see just how strong bond they have to each other. And, when the male penguin couldn't find a place for the "nest" that was good enough for her, she didn't waste any time at al and went directly to the closest handsome, available, male penguin that had found a Good place for a nest. And they, that new couple, startad to have sex with each others - right infront of her old partner. He looked so sad.  So, that's how strong bond these penguins actually have to each others. Maybe you thought about the large ones, they have a different kind of partnerships. But maybe not these, the small ones. They are cruel to each others ... at least the female ones. The only things they think about seems to be good real estate.  Perhaps it was he, the penguin, who Herzog captured with the camera, when he ventured away into the central of Antarctica, to his awaiting death, presumably.

I love the woods in the Americas, I grew up in Appalachia, then lived in a 40 acre pine forest in Michigan, on to the Rocky Mountains, had a cabin in the forest near Mt. About climate change: if Jordan Peterson thinks that we are going to spend a lot of money trying to stop climate change, he obviously does not realize how much we are going to spend dealing with it if we don't stop it.  So he wants cheap?  Fine, then spend trillions now to slow climate change down and start to degrow.  But if you want to go totally bust, just keep acting like doing anything is too expensive and put your head in the sand like Jordan Peterson.  Truth be told, I suspect we will continue to basically ignore it because to stop climate change and a myraid of related problems like resource scarcity requires degrowth, and there is next to zero political or social appetite for that.  Instead people want to keep on doing exactly what we have been doing, but instead of industrial revolution, they want the "green revolution".  It doesn't matter what you call it, but if we don't degrow intentionally, we will degrow through mass suffering from climate change, food insecurity, water insecurity, resource depleation, top soil depleation, and it goes on and on and on...  The choice really is ours, but just know that not doing anything is still doing _something_.

Hello Lex, first of all I want to thank you for what you do, it's a pleasure to listen to your conversations. After several years of listening to Joe and you, I have even improved my English. Secondly, I wanted to put a point of view on the table. As usual, in many programs the topic of what we should change or improve as a society comes up and things like that. You jump around many ideas but I haven't seen you discuss the idea of democracy or direct democracy. It's a topic that has been on my mind for years and I don't hear anyone asking these questions. Is this the ultimate state of democracy? Can we have a fairer democracy? Why don't we vote for measures, laws, and reforms instead of voting for people? Imagine how different the world would be if instead of voting for people, colors, or teams, we voted for ideas. How much would corruption decrease if we reduce the power of politicians? The idea of direct democracy is as old as democracy itself, and with current technology, it could be a very interesting game board without really making so many changes. It would be very interesting if this started to be discussed seriously both in academic circles and in public. I hope you can bring up the topic with a guest. I don't know if I'm too late or too early to the conversation. I'm writing this message because I've listened to too many episodes of your podcast and Joe's where this idea comes to my mind and I can't get rid of it. I'm writing it hoping that by some stroke of luck, I'll be lucky enough for you to read it. Again, a million thanks. If you travel to Seville, Spain, you have a friend here. Thanks also to Chat GPT for helping me write this message.

At 2:49:20: I've heard you say this a few times Lex, but I strongly disagree that wanting immortality is wanting to escape Earth's beauty. I want so badly to be "immortal," I want to choose when I die. I'm confident that I wouldn't choose to die for at least 500 years, but realistically I think I'd want to stick around for tens of thousands of years. Death is not beautiful or poetic, and it's not wrong to want to avoid it to study and experience life and Earth and everything else.  Humans barely get to 100 years old, and a good portion of those people are very different from when they were 50. Imagine if you got to keep your health and memories, and also had the freedom to explore the world and be a fly on the wall for several hundred years. Pre-agriculture, our life expectency was 20-30. Those ancient humans that wanted better health, bigger families, longer lives, etc. weren't trying to "escape the beauty for Earth." They weren't stupid, they saw the obvious value in living longer, and now today we couldn't imagine living only 20 years. Would post-immortality humans think the same about our 80-100 years?  I am disappointed so many people romanticize death. There's nothing glorious about it, we should hate it. The people that can't cope with the idea that death could be optional pretend instead that they aren't afraid. Being alive should keep you afraid of death, and should make you want to go out kicking and screaming because you were born in the pre-immortality ages.  "Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light."

This something your guest should be aware of, but also anyone lucky enough to read this. I ask only one thing of anyone smart enough to adopt this method of wound treatment. You must tell at least one other human about this discovery. This is something I have been doing for over twenty years and have found every bit of it to be absolute truth. I wondered why medicine hasnt adopted this treatment when I know it is done for plastic surgery in face lifts. Which simplified, you make a laceration at a certain angle removing tissue then joining those lines together. They use a light tape to keep the line closed. What this does is allow the body to do a reversal of healing, by healing the inner part of the wound first and not creating scar tissue, then healing the outer dermal layer last, written in that person's DNA. Then I realized the first time they tape a wound in the ER, that person is never coming back, nor anyone they know.  At first, I thought this method would only be good for lacerations, because they are the easiest wounds to heal with no scaring because of this reversal in healing. Then over the years learned it works with any and all wounds to the body. Even severe burns.  The key to this method is the lack of three vital aspects that are not present in this method. First is pain throughout the complete healing time with absolutely none. Matter of fact, that wound, no matter how bad, will be off of your mind completely. Second, is no infection whatsoever based on this tape fooling the body into thinking there is no breach and healing in reverse, not allowing air to get to the wound.  Pain or any sensation to any wound is because the body is telling you there are germs getting into the wound. Third being no scar whatsoever, but you must keep tape on the wound until it is completely gone. I personally did an experiment on an abrasion to my forearm. I put one dressing on the wound and didnt remove it until the wound was healed two weeks later. You just know it is time to take it off. Absolutely no trace that a wound was under that tape. Where the tape touched the actual wound, the adhesive was gone and absorbed by the body. Actually you can go every two days clean the wound with water then re-tape immediately with an emphasis on keeping lacerations closed completely. All other wounds, just keep the wound covered at all times. Use water to help remove the tape, and never ever rip the tape off.  This will cause secondary injuries around the wound.  The problem with store bought cloth tape, is the adhesive isnt aggressive enough to stay on the wounds at all times until you are ready to remove it for cleaning. What I use is an athletic tape used for wrapping joints to allow the athlete to perform with injuries. Any wound to an area that has hair must have the hair removed completely. Never ever put anything under the tape with the wound, especially gauze. That allows air to get to it and infection will happen. Even mild infections that only give redness around the wound will have that wound on your mind throughout the healing process for one reason or another, even if you take any pain it might provide, taking longer to heal as well. The way you know it is time to remove the tape is to touch the wound or rub it, and if any sensation is felt, it is not time to remove it.  The greatest thing to the discovery of this method of healing, is no child will ever have to suffer from any wound, ever again. The only time you will ever need medical attention for any wound, is if you hit an artery.  Here is a link to the tape similar to mine, as mine is not available at this time on Amazon.  https://www.amazon.com/BSN-Medical-BEI076168-Leukotape-Sports/dp/B000E59HXC?pd_rd_w=0RwQi&content-id=amzn1.sym.deffa092-2e99-4e9f-b814-0d71c40b24af&pf_rd_p=deffa092-2e99-4e9f-b814-0d71c40b24af&pf_rd_r=ZJG8GP4WPWZJ38G417V1&pd_rd_wg=UC1wL&pd_rd_r=b959be1f-6a33-477b-abb3-9002689c8f3e&psc=1&ref_=pd_bap_d_grid_rp_0_3_i  Mermaids are real, but you wont see them in the rivers of the Amazon.

My experience there lead me to the exact same description: a battlefield.   Every morning I would wake up and look across the floor to a hundred dead, half eaten, half alive insects. Every single night there was a war of insects, across the floor, walls and ceilings--centipedes, tarantulas, a variety of spiders, ants, and a hundred other bizarre insects. You can't leave your shoes out--and when you untucked your mosquito netting, you were very very careful with your first step onto the floor below you, because you knew that the half-living bugs would suddenly lurch and skitter across the the floor to get to the corners.

1:43:20 - Here Lex is actually referring to the Zahavi's 'handicap principle'. In order to understand this it helps to think about signalling games in game theory. Basically, as long as it is harder for an unfit male to have a certain handicap than for a fit male to have a certain handicap, then having that handicap can signal high fitness to potential mates. Having a big peacock tail is hard, it weights you down and makes flying harder. Therefore, only the fittest peacocks can handle suffering such a "handicap", and females can infer from how big this tail or handicap is the fitness of the male. :)

You bet wild animals look out for each other. The other day, their was an injured fledgling grackle in my backyard. All helpless with its mouth open sprawled out on the grass, crying out for help. Sure enough, its mama comes by and feeds it. So I'm like, cool, it's getting help. The next day, it's still out there lying in the grass, no other birds around, so I called the local wild bird center, and they asked me if I could bring it to them. So I grabbed a shoebox and a small towel and went to gently capture the little guy. As soon as I got close all hell broke loose. A plague of grackles start dive bombing me then a murder of crows swoop in, even a few mockingbirds show up to start chirping about it. I had to put the shoebox on my head and and flee the scene. The crows followed me to my front door dive bombing the whole way. I even saw one writing down my address. They even posted a scout in my palm tree. Now whenever I  go outside they alert the whole neighborhood. So now I'm a marked man for trying to do a good deed ğŸ˜‚

The best coffee is from Peru. It figures. The place is breathtakingly beautiful. I probably shouldn't say that. My favorite light organic coffee from Peru, is already in limited supply from all of my favorite brands. :-) I used to like hearing the stories that I heard or read from an early age about how the Indians used to respect the killing of the animals. They thanked the animal for their life sacrificed to sustain their own lives before the killing of the animal. That deep respect for the animals always stayed with me over the years. We use animals so carelessly. It's kind of outstanding how much we use animals products for. Even musical instruments can have animal products in them. Who knew? I don't even want to think about the clothing items, that I've accumulated. It's overwhelming. I still remember watching so many videos of the mass slaughter of animals in factories. The worst was seeing the mother animals with their young. I have a tender heart for the mother animals. And, then slaughter day came around. One machine slaughtered chicken in particular struggled so much after it's neck was cut and he was bleeding out. He seriously did not want to die. I could see it in his eyes, how he almost wanted to ask why was this happening? That was rough. The other chickens seemed to accept their fate. That image has stayed with me over the years. I still go to Chick-fil-A though. Sadly enough. I feel conflicted about it, if I think about it. Especially when I start to complain about the chicken not being crispy or juicy enough. It's a rough life. Having access to certain foods that keep my wellness and everything else in check is a miracle that I sometimes get used to. I should remember to make more of an effort to pray and thank God for my food/sustenance, more often. I feel the gratefulness. I just forget to voice it sometimes. :-) I feel the gratefulness for Lex podcasts. They are of great value to me. I enjoy bingeing on them. Maybe it's just because I enjoy bingeing on Lex. :-) Lex has a beautiful heart and mind. I hope that it always stays that way. Life is a long journey if you live long enough. :-)

Great chat. Concerning aggressive snakes; maybe Paul has not encountered a water moccasin/cottonmouth on the river? I had an experience with a water moccasin snorkeling down the middle of the Kings River in Arkansas with my wife at least 20 ft from either shore in about 6 ft of water, just after I had told my wife not to worry about snakes, I stood up in the water ahead of my wife to clear my mask of fog and here comes a 4ft water moccasin from the shore fast swimming at us. I stood between it and my wife and told her to stay back and waited and as it got within 5ft of me I gave it a huge splash to scare it away and to my surprise, as I continued to splash massive amounts of water it actually swam into the splashing water at me very aggressively sort of springing at me back and forth. All I could do was keep violently splashing back at it backing up for about 5-10 seconds until it reluctantly swam away. It totally changed my perspective on snakes in the river.
