When the Yellowstone supervolcano erupts, which it will, as it does on a regular basis, it will pour sulfuric ash into the atmosphere that will rain down as acid rain, acidifying the ocean, the rivers, streams, soil, causing more devastation than all human pollution. It will devastate most of North America pretty immediately, killing all the plants and animals, including the ones on our endangered species' lists. It will block out the sun, killing more plants and animals in a broader portion of Earth. Toba supervolcano will also erupt again on its own cycle, and destroy the other side of the world. There are other supervolcanoes, and each one will do more damage than we do and will undo everything we do to try to "save the planet".  And that's what nature is.

I did ayahuasca 11 years go in hope of getting over a mental problem (which I found out later was pure O OCD). Long story short it didn't help with that one bit but I went through a whole spectrum of good/bad experiences over 7 ayahuasca sessions. Some of the early ones were pretty much duds. Then some were more pleasant and possibly even instructional, but some were remarkably tough ...  one was absolutely terrifying... when he talks about being disassociated from himself and being alone it was kinda like that but this terrifying sense of complete loneliness. Like being trapped in a hell outside of time. And I desperately wanted to get out but I couldn't. The most unpleasant experience of my life. And you never hear those stories wen you research it before you go - you hear all the best ones. So just beware. You take the good with the bad. That's not to say you shouldn't go and do it. Not at all. But just know that there can be bad trips among the good ones. Be ready for that and don't expect just good things. Don't expect anything at all actually. Because it's unlikely you'll get it. I don't regret doing it but I wish I hadn't been sold a false idea by snake oil salesmen.

Brazil has best preservation laws and practices...66% of country is preserved....  every farm has to have 20% of native land preserved even in the cerrado( savana)... our energy is mostly hydreletric... its one of the most clean in the world if not the most. "You find out what you believe in"  but you figure out what to do etc. This is the strange psychology of fear that makes people say dumb stuff like "there are no atheists in foxholes" when what they really mean is "pray to God but swim for the shore". People don't chose what they believe in and nor are they always honest, even with themselves, about what they truly believe. You are either convinced that X is true for good or bad reasons. I've never come across a good reason to believe in God. If I made a death bed conversion it would be Pascal's Wager at best. It's not a good reason to believe in god, it is a desperate hope for something which it would be disingenuous for me to say I was convinced. Same with numinous experience: it tells you nothing of the source of your awe. Dennett's notion of belief in belief seems to me to cover most convictions held with insufficient evidence.

I'm sorry but I disagree entirely. Ayahuasca is an experience that was cultivated and crafted by a culture for years beyond counting. It is an experience that is defined by the jungle, it's plants, the animals that coexist with them, and the people that uncovered this experience from the jungle that they consider a mother to them, and allows them to become one with it, for themselves and for their people. THAT is ayahuasca. If you drink a tea in your living room, to me at least, you are just doing DMT. There's nothing wrong with that, and it can be positive and beautiful, but understand that you are doing a drug, and not going through a shamanic ritual that "doing ayahuasca" is. It's nice that you know the name of the drink they prepare, and appreciate its power, but to be entirely truthful, saying that you doing that in your living room in the u.s is the same or superior to a spiritual tradition that we can't even put a date on that gave you that drug IN THE FIRST PLACE is disrespectful to the medicine, the people that uncovered it, and bastardizes what "ayahuasca" means.

Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  I'm sure the jungle brings it's own unique beauty and depth to the experience but I did it at a beautiful place in Florida. Outdoors with lots of trees and fire and they bring in the Shamans. Felt absolutely beautiful and amazing. Nothing seemed missing. I think the whole need to do it in the jungle thing is kind of an outdated concept that people like to repeat because it sounds good say. I understand that people like to keep things traditional but I just don't think it's necessary.
Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  gahdayum gg
Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  if you had my experience you would disagree with yourself

â€‹Â @scentwarsÂ  I'm glad that you had such a good experience. Truly, I'm not trying to say that anyone's psychedelic experience wasn't valid or meaningful... However... You almost certainly did not take ayahuasca from a true shaman. I don't mean a guy from Texas that got really into ayahuasca and started calling himself a shaman, or a native person from South America that found out they could make money by saying they were a shaman and doing a ritual for gullible westerners. I'm talking about REAL shamans from the rainforest that carry on this timeless tradition of their ancestors.   The reason I'm fairly certain you did not have one of these real shamans is, frankly, they don't leave the jungle. Why would they? Money? Don't need it in the jungle. Fame? The concept of being known outside the local area, or driving value from it doesn't exist for them. Helping others? There are no people on earth that need more people than the indigenous people living in the Amazon, their very own people, why would they go out of their way to help the people that, from their point of view, are why they are struggling in the first place.   There is literally no motivation for a real shaman to leave the rainforest. The only one I'm aware of doing it regularly is Davi Kopenawa, and that's because he is desperately trying to save his forest, and giving foreigners their spritual medicine is the last thing on his mind.   As far as nothing being missing: for DMT, you are absolutely correct. Nothing would be missing because there isn't a tradition from which anything CAN be missing. As far as ayahuasca... well... listen to the accounts of people who have taken it in the jungle vs in the modern world. It's different. It's different because the ingredients used are different, they just have more stuff in the Amazon to mix in than we have here, and only real shamans would know about that. People report hallucinating the same things in the jungle, whole groups seeing anaconda or jaguar, to the point that researchers early on thought that ayahuasca caused telepathy. That stuff doesn't really happen in the modern setting.   Again, I respect your DMT experience and an happy it was meaningful and beautiful for you. But I have to be straightforward in that I also think that saying that you "did ayahuasca and think the jungle isn't necessary" is massively disrespectful to the culture and people that made that experience even possible for you. As far as I am concerned, you did DMT in a shaman-y setting and you had a good experience, and I think that's great. Did you go through a serious spiritual ritual with a shaman to guide you in the way its been done in the rainforest forever? I would say not.

Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  I understand your opinion, but it does not match up to my lived experience... One of my facilitators lived with a Shaman in the Amazon for almost a year and she trained him. During my journey I "travelled" to the Amazon visually and spiritually. I could 100% feel like i was in the middle of the Amazon with 3 entities and Mother Aya guiding me through it... To say you can only have this experience in the Amazon means most of the world will not get to have this experience simply because they can not afford to go to one specific location on the other side of the world. It's not how Aya works. Aya does not have an owner. If anything it has taught me that we all are our own "shamans". In the Amazon you are also just "taking a drug", location makes no difference. I've heard of many dodgy "shamans" in the Amazon too... Aya wants to be shared with all humanity, not kept confined to one geographic location.

Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  "People report hallucinating the same things in the jungle, whole groups seeing anaconda or jaguar, to the point that researchers early on thought that ayahuasca caused telepathy. That stuff doesn't really happen in the modern setting.."  Yes it does happen in a modern setting, same visions etc... I had three animal spirits in my visions. A snake, a jaguar and a crocodile... All three were helping guide me through the jungle, plus Mother Aya's all encompassing presence.  I spent 2 weeks doing dieta and doing nothing but meditating before the experience. The moment it was time to drink, it felt like i had already drank it and Aya's spirit was already in me.  I live all the way in Australia. Geographical location means nothing. Mother Aya's spirit is all around us, you just have to tap into it.

Â @brutalisaxeworth3024Â  I know that's not exactly what you mean, but psychedelic experiences are not competing with one another. I have no doubt that there is a uniqueness about the traditional rituals and Shamans but there is also the factor of the individual taking part. The traditional lineage of what you're describing would only be complete if the participant in the ritual is also brought up in that tradition and tied in with the indigenous culture and habitat. A Western tourist brings his own consciousness to the experience. The OP's comment was about having psychedelic experiences for personal improvement or psychological benefit. The traditional experience may be unique (Although all psychedelic experiences are imo), but psychedelics are about an inner journey, a consciousness shift, healing trauma, and overcoming fears. The Shamanic rituals in the Amazon are developed by and for their specific culture, the Jungle and traditions carry with them their own cultural and traditional obstacles and psychological hurdles. So if a Western person wants to get the most benefit from a psychedelic experience, ayahuasca in the Amazon might not be the best way to go precisely because it is an alien setting to them. (mind)Set and setting are crucial for psychedelic experiences. If you are distracted by fear of the Jungle or feel uncomfortable in the traditional setting, it could affect your trip in various ways. That being said I loved reading your comment and your respect for the ancient tradition and I share your gratitude for these traditions to carry the psychedelic wisdom into our current time.

There were a couple of times near the end of the journey and after rapÃ© that i released a few entities through spitting into a bucket, but that was about it. Think the vomiting thing depends on the person and their diet leading up to consuming... I definitely would not be comparing LSD to Aya though, completely different.

Â @muszr00mÂ  fair enough, but I vomited extremely hard and my experience was fairly comparable to LSD. Hopefully we can at least agree that the DMT and MAOI combination is what leads to the psychedelic experience, not the extra 99% of bark/mud in the mix.
